Go On Make An Exhibition Of Yourself - Advice From Dan

Weekly Bulletin - October 2012

I recently wrote a whitepaper on the subject of 'Go On, Make An Exhibition of Yourself' as the trade show season was approaching. I examined how exhibitions can be an important strategic tool - provided your attendance is properly planned, executed and followed up.

A friend and ex-colleague of mine, and well-known sales leader Dan Wabiszewski has added his 'take' on the document, contributing his expertise and some extremely useful practical hints and tips:

'Forecast and Budget: If you attend multiple events a year, take the time to forecast costs and assign a specific budget to each event. Create a template to estimate and track all costs. All the minutiae that goes into a successful stand (furniture, electrical, lead scanner, plants) adds up very quickly, and many novice marketing staff fail to account for it. Take some time and create a spreadsheet template that covers EVERYTHING.

Track Results Religiously:Grading leads is critical, but it is also important to track the leads. Make sure you assign the lead source and treat the trade show as a trackable campaign. This is easily done in any advanced CRM system such as Salesforce. Although tracking a trade show lead to a closed sale can be difficult and somewhat unfair, it is just like any other marketing program. You need to map your lead funnel and track opportunities in your pipeline to an exhibition. A large quantity of leads makes everyone happy but, in the end, quality wins the day. Increase your resources to the exhibits that show the best results and reduce your footprint in shows that are mediocre, yet need a presence to remain relevant.

Planning:For major trade shows, planning is a YEAR LONG process and your business should not and cannot grind to halt a month before and during the exhibit. After the show:

Follow-up on your leads and set appointments with your opportunities.

Plan for next year. Immediately take the time to debrief. Compare objectives with results. Don't wait six months and rely on hearsay. If you do it right you can have 75% of your planning complete 9 months before the show.

Staffing: I have too many hard earned lessons regarding staffing to fit here. But here are some thoughts:

Your staff must be 100% committed to the event. Sales and marketing staff need to devote all of their energies to the show. They cannot show up late, leave early or ask to be excused to get a quote out. They should make every effort that their task list is clear during the event. If they can't they should stay away and keep selling.

Everyone in the booth is selling and it is a TEAM event. Just because your territory is EMEA doesn't mean you can't build rapport with the Canadian prospect who walked onto the stand. Engage the customer as much as possible and pass on to the right rep when appropriate. Technical, marketing and executive management are there to sell as well. If not, don't hang around.

Avoid staff socials. Train them, yes. Entertain them, no. The staff dinner is great, but it is a grind and a massive waste of money. Sales people should be engaging customers or at least catching up and unwinding/ recuperating for the next day. If you want to have team time keep it simple and release them early.

Focus Training On Producing Results At The Trade Show Only:Just because you have everyone in the same place, doesn't mean it's time to do CRM training don't make it a grind before the show even begins.

Be Smart With Your Attraction:Avoid the massive vendor party. How many vendor parties have you attended? Do you remember the vendor? Exactly. Unless you are a big name or throw an over the top, over budget event, they won't remember you. That being said, maximize your attraction and create events for continued interaction. In this case consider training sessions, lunch and learns and credible educational events that make your prospects leave the show floor to see you. And as a final tip never serve alcohol on your stand!'
